title.text: Correlation between Weak La Niña and Accumulated Rainfall

caption.text:
Pearson correlation coefficient: 0.31

The value 0.31 indicates Weak La Niña has a weak positive correlation with Accumulated Rainfall in ARGHAKHANCHI. This is based on analysis of Accumulated Rainfall behavior in ARGHAKHANCHI from 1980 to 2012 where Weak La Niña was recorded.

title.text: Correlation between Weak El Niño and Cummulative Rainfall

caption.text:
Pearson correlation coefficient: -0.09

The value -0.09 indicates Weak El Niño has a very weak negative correlation with Cummulative Rainfall in ARGHAKHANCHI. This is based on analysis of Cummulative Rainfall behavior in ARGHAKHANCHI from 1982 to 2013 where Weak El Niño was recorded.

title.text: Correlation between MJO and Rainfall Anomaly

caption.text:
Pearson correlation coefficient: -0.09

The value -0.09 indicates MJO Phase has a very weak negative correlation with Rainfall in ARGHAKHANCHI. This is based on analysis of Cummulative Rainfall behavior in ARGHAKHANCHI from 1982 to 2013 where Weak MJO was recorded.

title.text: Scatter Plot - Observed vs Predicted Cummulative Rainfall

caption.text: Points closer to the line indicate accurate predictions

title.text: Normal vs Monthly Averages during La Niña Years

caption.text:
La Niña Events are defined as 5 consecutive overlapping 3-month periods at or below the -0.5 anomaly.
    For an event to be categorized as weak, moderate, strong or very strong it must have equaled or exceeded the threshold of the highest category for at least 3 consecutive overlapping 3-month periods.
    The threshold is further broken down into the following: 
    Weak (with a -0.5 to -0.9), 
    Moderate (-1.0 to -1.4), 
    Strong (-1.5 to -1.9), and 
    Very Strong (≤ -2.0) events.

title.text: Normal vs Monthly Averages during El Niño Years

caption.text:
El Niño Events are defined as 5 consecutive overlapping 3-month periods at or above the +0.5 anomaly.
    For an event to be categorized as weak, moderate, strong or very strong it must have equaled or exceeded the threshold of the highest category for at least 3 consecutive overlapping 3-month periods.
    The threshold is further broken down into the following: 
    Weak (with a 0.5 to 0.9), 
    Moderate (1.0 to 1.4), 
    Strong (1.5 to 1.9), and 
    Very Strong (≥ 2.0) events.

title.text: Normal vs Daily Averages per Month during Days of MJO Phases 1 to 8 and Weak MJO

caption.text: The Madden-Julian Oscillation (MJO) is the major fluctuation in tropical weather on weekly to monthly timescales. The Real-time Multivariate MJO (RMM) index defines MJO through projection of daily anomaly data onto the leading pair of empirical orthogonal functions of the combined fields of equatorially-averaged Outgoing Longwave Radiation to obtain two principal component time series called RMM1 and RMM2. The RMM1 and RMM2 indices define a 2D phase space. This phase space is used to define eight "strong" MJO phases, each corresponding to the geographical position of its active convective center. A Weak MJO category defined when the recorded amplitude in a day is less than 1.

title.text: Normal vs Daily Averages per Month during Days of MJO Phases 1 to 8 and Weak MJO
Wheat Water Requirements vs Observed Rainfall
Wheat Temperature Thresholds vs Observed Temperature

crop_analysis:
Crop: Wheat
Season: November, December, January, February, March, April
Location: ARGHAKHANCHI

Analysis: 

The water requirement for Wheat, during November, December, January, February, March, April is 24.59% of the average observed rainfall in the years 1994 to 2024. 

The temperature requirement for Wheat, during November, December, January, February, March, April is generally close to or within the range of the average observed temperature during the season in the years 1994 to 2024 of data.

This overall deficit in water requirement against rainfall and temperature requirement against the observed temperature are attributed to the following:
crop_recommendation:
The analysis suggests that the observed rainfall during November, December, January, February, March, April represents an overall 24.59% of Wheat's water requirement for its full crop production cycle. 

This suggests that Wheat production in ARGHAKHANCHI is driven by infrastructures and practices other than utilization of rainfall (e.g. irrigation network/system; underground water extraction). 

This implies that any disruption in the system for supplying water for Wheat cultivation/production during the season, could significantly impact crop cultivation/production. 

In the long-term, systems for supplying water for Wheat cultivation/production in ARGHAKHANCHI have to be sustainably ensured to maintain the crop production performance; unsustainable practices have to be addressed (e.g.  continuous ground water extraction to support the significant water deficit could have severe environmental impacts). 

Given available datasets, comprehensive development planning for Wheat production in ARGHAKHANCHI should include: 
a.) cost-benefit analysis for Wheat cultivation/production taking into context the resources/investments that have to be sustainably provided to maintain Wheat productivity and viability; 
b.) analysis of environmental impacts, including carbon emissions, vis-à-vis the activities/resources required to support Wheat cultivation/production in ARGHAKHANCHI, and the cultivation/production practices leading to Wheat harvesting and availability in markets; 
c.) engineering of new varieties of in-demand crops, to sustainably suit environmental conditions; and 
d.) Analysis of transitioning the crop lands in ARGHAKHANCHI into other crops or land uses more favorable in the context of observed climate, market demands, and environmental sustainability.
    
Furthermore, the analysis suggests that the observed temperature during November, December, January, February, March, April is overall close to or within the range of Wheat’s temperature requirement for its full crop production cycle. 

This suggests that successful Wheat cultivation/ production in ARGHAKHANCHI is seriously challenging to impossible in natural temperature conditions, per the analysis of temperature datasets in the years 1994 to 2024

In the future, and in case dire requirement for land for cultivation/production of Wheat is required, temperature-controlled systems, which requires significant investments, might be explored to make Wheat cultivation/production feasible in ARGHAKHANCHI. For this temperature-controlled systems to be sustainable, mechanisms to ensure low- to zero-carbon emissions have to be explored and put in place. 

Given available datasets, comprehensive development planning for Wheat production in ARGHAKHANCHI should include: 
a.) cost-benefit analysis for Wheat cultivation/production taking into context the resources/investments that have to be sustainably provided to maintain Wheat productivity and viability; 
b.) analysis of environmental impacts, including carbon emissions, vis-à-vis the activities/resources required to support Wheat cultivation/production in ARGHAKHANCHI, and the cultivation/production practices leading to Wheat harvesting and availability in markets; 
c.) engineering of new varieties of in-demand crops, to sustainably suit crops to environmental conditions; and 
d.) Analysis of transitioning the crop lands in ARGHAKHANCHI into other crops or land uses more favorable in the context of observed climate, market demands, and environmental sustainability.
